name: Ext.Function
doc: A collection of useful static methods to deal with function callbacks.

members.name: alias
members.doc: Create an alias to the provided method property with name methodName of object. Note that the execution scope will still be bound to the provided object itself.

params.name: object
params.html_type: Object/Function

params.name: methodName

members.short_doc: Create an alias to the provided method property with name methodName of object. ...

members.name: bind
members.doc:
Create a new function from the provided fn, change this to the provided scope, optionally overrides arguments for the call. Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller.

Ext.bind is alias for Ext.Function.bind

NOTE: This method is similar to the native bind() method. The major difference is in the way the parameters are passed. This method expects an array of parameters, and if supplied, it does not automatically pass forward parameters from the bound function:

 function foo (a, b, c) {
     console.log(a, b, c);
 }

 var nativeFn = foo.bind(this, 1, 2);
 var extFn = Ext.Function.bind(foo, this, [1, 2]);

 nativeFn(3); // 1, 2, 3
 extFn(3); // 1, 2, undefined

This method is unavailable natively on IE8 and IE/Quirks but Ext JS provides a "polyfill" to emulate the important features of the standard bind method. In particular, the polyfill only provides binding of "this" and optional arguments.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to delegate.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the global environment object (usually the browser window).

params.name: args
params.doc: Overrides arguments for the call. (Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller).

params.name: appendArgs
params.doc: if true the args are appended to the arguments passed to the returned wrapper (by default these arguments are ignored). If a number then the args are inserted at the specified position.
params.html_type: Boolean/Number

members.short_doc:
Create a new function from the provided fn, change this to the provided scope,
optionally overrides arguments for the...

members.name: bindCallback
members.doc:
Captures the given parameters for a later call to Ext.callback. This binding is most useful for resolving scopes for example to an Ext.app.ViewController.

The arguments match that of Ext.callback except for the args which, if provided to this method, are prepended to any arguments supplied by the eventual caller of the returned function.

return.name: return
return.doc: A function that, when called, uses Ext.callback to call the captured callback.

members.short_doc: Captures the given parameters for a later call to Ext.callback. ...

members.name: clone
members.doc: Create a "clone" of the provided method. The returned method will call the given method passing along all arguments and the "this" pointer and return its result.

params.name: method

members.short_doc: Create a "clone" of the provided method. ...

members.name: createAnimationFrame
members.doc: Creates a wrapped function that, when invoked, defers execution until the next animation frame

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to call.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. Defaults to the window object.

params.name: args
params.doc: The argument list to pass to the function.

params.name: queueStrategy
params.doc:
A bit flag that indicates how multiple calls to the returned function within the same animation frame should be handled.

  • 1: All calls will be queued - FIFO order
  • 2: Only the first call will be queued
  • 3: The last call will replace all previous calls

members.short_doc:
Creates a wrapped function that, when invoked, defers execution until the next
animation frame ...

members.name: createBarrier
members.doc: Wraps the passed function in a barrier function which will call the passed function after the passed number of invocations.

params.name: count
params.doc: The number of invocations which will result in the calling of the passed function.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to call after the required number of invocations.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function will be called.

members.short_doc:
Wraps the passed function in a barrier function which will call the passed function
after the passed number of invoca...

members.name: createBuffered
members.doc: Creates a delegate function, optionally with a bound scope which, when called, buffers the execution of the passed function for the configured number of milliseconds. If called again within that period, the impending invocation will be canceled, and the timeout period will begin again.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to invoke on a buffered timer.

params.name: buffer
params.doc: The number of milliseconds by which to buffer the invocation of the function.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which. the passed function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the scope specified by the caller.

params.name: args
params.doc: Override arguments for the call. Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller.

return.name: return
return.doc: A function which invokes the passed function after buffering for the specified time.

members.short_doc:
Creates a delegate function, optionally with a bound scope which, when called, buffers
the execution of the passed fu...

members.name: createDelayed
members.doc: Creates a delegate (callback) which, when called, executes after a specific delay.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function which will be called on a delay when the returned function is called. Optionally, a replacement (or additional) argument list may be specified.

params.name: delay
params.doc: The number of milliseconds to defer execution by whenever called.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) used by the function at execution time.

params.name: args
params.doc: Override arguments for the call. (Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller)

params.name: appendArgs
params.doc: if True args are appended to call args instead of overriding, if a number the args are inserted at the specified position.
params.html_type: Boolean/Number

return.name: return
return.doc: A function which, when called, executes the original function after the specified delay.

members.short_doc: Creates a delegate (callback) which, when called, executes after a specific delay. ...

members.name: createInterceptor
members.doc:
Creates an interceptor function. The passed function is called before the original one. If it returns false, the original one is not called. The resulting function returns the results of the original function. The passed function is called with the parameters of the original function. Example usage:

var sayHi = function(name){
    alert('Hi, ' + name);
};

sayHi('Fred'); // alerts "Hi, Fred"

// create a new function that validates input without
// directly modifying the original function:
var sayHiToFriend = Ext.Function.createInterceptor(sayHi, function(name){
    return name === 'Brian';
});

sayHiToFriend('Fred');  // no alert
sayHiToFriend('Brian'); // alerts "Hi, Brian"

params.name: origFn
params.doc: The original function.

params.name: newFn
params.doc: The function to call before the original.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the passed function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the scope in which the original function is called or the browser window.

params.name: returnValue
params.doc: The value to return if the passed function return false.

members.name: createSequence
members.doc:
Create a combined function call sequence of the original function + the passed function. The resulting function returns the results of the original function. The passed function is called with the parameters of the original function. Example usage:

var sayHi = function(name){
    alert('Hi, ' + name);
};

sayHi('Fred'); // alerts "Hi, Fred"

var sayGoodbye = Ext.Function.createSequence(sayHi, function(name){
    alert('Bye, ' + name);
});

sayGoodbye('Fred'); // both alerts show

params.name: originalFn
params.doc: The original function.

params.name: newFn
params.doc: The function to sequence.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the passed function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the scope in which the original function is called or the default global environment object (usually the browser window).

members.short_doc: Create a combined function call sequence of the original function + the passed function. ...

members.name: createThrottled
members.doc:
Creates a throttled version of the passed function which, when called repeatedly and rapidly, invokes the passed function only after a certain interval has elapsed since the previous invocation.

This is useful for wrapping functions which may be called repeatedly, such as a handler of a mouse move event when the processing is expensive.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to execute at a regular time interval.

params.name: interval
params.doc: The interval in milliseconds on which the passed function is executed.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the passed function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the scope specified by the caller.

return.name: return
return.doc: A function which invokes the passed function at the specified interval.

members.short_doc:
Creates a throttled version of the passed function which, when called repeatedly and
rapidly, invokes the passed func...

members.name: defer
members.doc:
Calls function fn after the number of milliseconds specified, optionally with a specific scope (this pointer).

Example usage:

var sayHi = function(name) {
    alert('Hi, ' + name);
}

// executes immediately:
sayHi('Fred');

// executes after 2 seconds:
Ext.defer(sayHi, 2000, this, ['Fred']);

The following syntax is useful for scheduling anonymous functions:

Ext.defer(function() {
    alert('Anonymous');
}, 100);

NOTE: The Ext.Function.defer() method is an alias for Ext.defer().

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to defer.

params.name: millis
params.doc: The number of milliseconds for the setTimeout call (if less than or equal to 0 the function is executed immediately).

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the browser window.

params.name: args
params.doc: Overrides arguments for the call. Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller.

params.name: appendArgs
params.doc: If true args are appended to call args instead of overriding, or, if a number, then the args are inserted at the specified position.
params.html_type: Boolean/Number

return.name: return
return.doc: The timeout id that can be used with Ext.undefer.

members.short_doc:
Calls function fn after the number of milliseconds specified, optionally with
a specific scope (this pointer). ...

members.name: flexSetter
members.doc:
A very commonly used method throughout the framework. It acts as a wrapper around another method which originally accepts 2 arguments for name and value. The wrapped function then allows "flexible" value setting of either:

  • name and value as 2 arguments
  • one single object argument with multiple key - value pairs

For example:

var setValue = Ext.Function.flexSetter(function(name, value) {
    this[name] = value;
});

// Afterwards
// Setting a single name - value
setValue('name1', 'value1');

// Settings multiple name - value pairs
setValue({
    name1: 'value1',
    name2: 'value2',
    name3: 'value3'
});

params.name: setter
params.doc: The single value setter method.

properties.name: name
properties.doc: The name of the value being set.

members.short_doc: A very commonly used method throughout the framework. ...

members.name: interceptAfter
members.doc:
Adds behavior to an existing method that is executed after the original behavior of the function. For example:

var soup = {
    contents: [],
    add: function(ingredient) {
        this.contents.push(ingredient);
    }
};
Ext.Function.interceptAfter(soup, "add", function(ingredient){
    // Always add a bit of extra salt
    this.contents.push("salt");
});
soup.add("water");
soup.add("onions");
soup.contents; // will contain: water, salt, onions, salt

params.name: object
params.doc: The target object

params.name: methodName
params.doc: Name of the method to override

params.name: fn
params.doc: Function with the new behavior. It will be called with the same arguments as the original method. The return value of this function will be the return value of the new method.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope to execute the interceptor function. Defaults to the object.

members.short_doc:
Adds behavior to an existing method that is executed after the
original behavior of the function. ...

members.name: interceptBefore
members.doc:
Adds behavior to an existing method that is executed before the original behavior of the function. For example:

var soup = {
    contents: [],
    add: function(ingredient) {
        this.contents.push(ingredient);
    }
};
Ext.Function.interceptBefore(soup, "add", function(ingredient){
    if (!this.contents.length && ingredient !== "water") {
        // Always add water to start with
        this.contents.push("water");
    }
});
soup.add("onions");
soup.add("salt");
soup.contents; // will contain: water, onions, salt

params.name: object
params.doc: The target object

params.name: methodName
params.doc: Name of the method to override

params.name: fn
params.doc: Function with the new behavior. It will be called with the same arguments as the original method. The return value of this function will be the return value of the new method.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope to execute the interceptor function. Defaults to the object.

members.short_doc:
Adds behavior to an existing method that is executed before the
original behavior of the function. ...

members.name: interval
members.doc:
Calls the function fn repeatedly at a given interval, optionally with a specific scope (this pointer).

var sayHi = function(name) {
    console.log('Hi, ' + name);
}

// executes every 2 seconds:
var timerId = Ext.interval(sayHi, 2000, this, ['Fred']);

The timer is stopped by:

Ext.uninterval(timerId);

NOTE: The Ext.Function.interval() method is an alias for Ext.interval().

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to defer.

params.name: millis
params.doc: The number of milliseconds for the setInterval call

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. If omitted, defaults to the browser window.

params.name: args
params.doc: Overrides arguments for the call. Defaults to the arguments passed by the caller.

params.name: appendArgs
params.doc: If true args are appended to call args instead of overriding, or, if a number, then the args are inserted at the specified position.
params.html_type: Boolean/Number

return.name: return
return.doc: The interval id that can be used with Ext.uninterval.

members.short_doc:
Calls the function fn repeatedly at a given interval, optionally with a
specific scope (this pointer). ...

members.name: memoize
members.doc:
Returns a wrapper function that caches the return value for previously processed function argument(s).

For example:

 function factorial (value) {
     var ret = value;

     while (--value > 1) {
         ret *= value;
     }

     return ret;
 }

Each call to factorial will loop and multiply to produce the answer. Using this function we can wrap the above and cache its answers:

 factorial = Ext.Function.memoize(factorial);

The returned function operates in the same manner as before, but results are stored in a cache to avoid calling the wrapped function when given the same arguments.

 var x = factorial(20);  // first time; call real factorial()
 var y = factorial(20);  // second time; return value from first call

To support multi-argument methods, you will need to provide a hashFn.

 function permutation (n, k) {
     return factorial(n) / factorial(n - k);
 }

 permutation = Ext.Function.memoize(permutation, null, function(n, k) {
     n + '-' + k;
 });

In this case, the memoize of factorial is sufficient optimization, but the example is simply to illustrate how to generate a unique key for an expensive, multi-argument method.

IMPORTANT: This cache is unbounded so be cautious of memory leaks if the memoized function is kept indefinitely or is given an unbounded set of possible arguments.

params.name: fn
params.doc: Function to wrap.

params.name: scope
params.doc: Optional scope in which to execute the wrapped function.

params.name: hashFn
params.doc: Optional function used to compute a hash key for storing the result, based on the arguments to the original function.

members.short_doc:
Returns a wrapper function that caches the return value for previously
processed function argument(s). ...

members.name: pass
members.doc:
Create a new function from the provided fn, the arguments of which are pre-set to args. New arguments passed to the newly created callback when it's invoked are appended after the pre-set ones. This is especially useful when creating callbacks.

For example:

var originalFunction = function(){
    alert(Ext.Array.from(arguments).join(' '));
};

var callback = Ext.Function.pass(originalFunction, ['Hello', 'World']);

callback(); // alerts 'Hello World'
callback('by Me'); // alerts 'Hello World by Me'

Ext.pass is alias for Ext.Function.pass

params.name: fn
params.doc: The original function.

params.name: args
params.doc: The arguments to pass to new callback.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed.

members.short_doc:
Create a new function from the provided fn, the arguments of which are pre-set
to args. ...

members.name: requestAnimationFrame
members.doc: Schedules the passed function to be called on the next animation frame.

params.name: fn
params.doc: The function to call.

params.name: scope
params.doc: The scope (this reference) in which the function is executed. Defaults to the window object.

params.name: args
params.doc: The argument list to pass to the function.

return.name: return
return.doc: Timer id for the new animation frame to use when canceling it.

members.short_doc: Schedules the passed function to be called on the next animation frame. ...
